large4:
MAY 2021
Infra Newsletter
 
Hi everyone 👋
 
Were continuing the process of the periodic Infra newsletter started some time ago to keep increasing the transparency of our work.

This one is a bit different. Well not only focus on the achievements, but will also share some useful knowledge about infrastructure, and our impressions about the KubeCon EU 2021 conference.
 
 
📓 Table of Contents
 
👩‍💻 Some statistics
💪 Achievements
🤖 Using Renovate to update asdfs .tool-versions
🚀 Triggering Jenkins rubs from GitHub Actions
🧠 Knowledge Sharing
🛂  Dependabot runs have limited permissions in GitHub
 KubeCon EU 2021  
@Ahmed's Pick: 👮 Shifting Policy Enforcement to the Left using GitOps
@Chaima's Pick: 🚀 Take your Project Docs to the Next Level
@Chriss Pick: 🔓TechDocs: Unlocking the Potential of Engineers' Collective Knowledge
@Larss Pick: 🏡 Automating Your Home with K3s and Home Assistant
@Maxs Pick: 🔥 We Didnt Start the Fire: Communication Breakdowns and How to Prevent Them
 
 
👩‍💻 Some Statistics
 
Over previous month (April 2021):
 

 
41 requests
 
answered in #infra, from 9 different teams
  

 
43 tickets
 
completed in Jira, 14 of them coming from other teams' requests
  

 
24k+ builds
 
ran in all Jenkins CI instances, over 800 builds per day!
 
 
💪 Achievements 
 
🤖Using Renovate to update asdfs .tool-versions
Many of Camunda Engineering teams use Renovate to automatically update project dependencies and save time. Some teams also use asdf to easily manage multiple runtimes for their projects and avoid tedious manual setup steps.

Have you been annoyed that Renovate does not support updating asdf dependencies in .tool-versions? Theres a workaround! Check out how Infra is doing it here, here, and in action.

Whom you can ask more about it: @Christian Nicolai
 
 
🚀Triggering Jenkins runs from GitHub Actions
When migrating CI processs to GitHub Actions, its often not feasible to do everything at once - for whatever reason, you might want to keep some legacy jobs in Jenkins.

By leveraging an official Jenkins API, we can now trigger these jobs from any GitHub Actions process. Its also possible to wait for their status and stream the logs.

This API is currently only available for Cawemo CI, but can be enabled on request.

Whom you can ask more about it: @Leonhardt Wille
 
 
 
🧠 Knowledge Sharing
 
🛂 Dependabot runs have limited permissions in GitHub
GitHub recently introduced a change that treats Dependabot PRs as though they are from a forked repository. This means that those PRs are subject to the limited access of e.g. repository secrets and can thereby fail if those are required in a GitHub action.

The Infrastructure team recommends switching to Renovate. If this is not feasible some workarounds can be found in this GitHub issue.
 
 
 
  KubeCon EU 2021
 
This year all Infra team members have participated in the biggest online Kubernetes-related conference in Europe. Wed like to share the talks weve enjoyed most (all talks are now available to the public), to get you inspired, and maybe youre about to join the next KubeCon yourself!
 
 
@Ahmed's Pick: 👮 Shifting Policy Enforcement to the Left using GitOps [Slides][Video]
Sandeep Parikh is a DevRel Engineer at Google Cloud. This talk is an application of DevSecOps concepts, it covers crossroads of different areas like Kubernetes, Open Policy Agent (aka OPA), automation via GitOps, and Shift-left concept. An interesting talk if you would like to know more about security, automation, and modern software practices. However it probably needs some basic knowledge about the mentioned topics.
 
 
@Chaima's Pick: 🚀 Take your Project Docs to the Next Level [Slides][Video]
Celeste Horgan is senior technical writer at the CNCF. She gave a very nice presentation for developers on how to create documentation and what are the main steps that should be present for a good documentation (concept, reference, tasks, and learn more). It was a nice break from very technical topics. Also, the presenter made a very interesting and coherent talk using a story telling way of presenting.
 
 
@Chriss Pick: 🔓 TechDocs: Unlocking the Potential of Engineers' Collective Knowledge [Slides][Video]
Emma Indal is a member of Spotifys technical documentation team (creators of Backstage) and gave a fascinating overview of the scale of their internal documentation platform with thousands of articles for hundreds of services. She shared how they achieved the goal of making documentation a first class citizen along code to improve the engineers experience.
 
 
@Larss Pick: 🏡 Automating Your Home with K3s and Home Assistant [GitHub][Video]
Eddie Zaneski and Jeff Billimek gave a brilliant talk at KubeCon about how they run their home automation with Home Assistant within a Kubernetes cluster at home. For this, they utilized a lightweight and production-ready Kubernetes distribution called K3s.

Both gave interesting insights into their home automation setup and how it can benefit from Kubernetes.

I recommend this talk to everyone interested in Kubernetes and/or home automation.
 
 
@Maxs Pick: 🔥 We Didnt Start the Fire: Communication Breakdowns and How to Prevent Them [Slides][Video]
Remember some time ago Dockershim was deprecated in k8s and people all over the world were freaking out, thinking k8s won't run their Docker images anymore?

The story is brilliantly told from the other side of the fence, and your palms do get sweaty when watching it.

Morale: Communication is crucial. Dont just assume what others think. Communicate, check the expectations, adapt. Together. MAY 2021

@Chaima's Pick: 🚀 Take your Project Docs to the Next Level [Slides][Video]
Celeste Horgan is senior technical writer at the CNCF. She gave a very nice presentation for developers on how to create documentation and what are the main steps that should be present for a good documentation (concept, reference, tasks, and learn more). It was a nice break from very technical topics. Also, the presenter made a very interesting and coherent talk using a story telling way of presenting.

Eddie Zaneski and Jeff Billimek gave a brilliant talk at KubeCon about how they run their home automation with Home Assistant within a Kubernetes cluster at home. For this, they utilized a lightweight and production-ready Kubernetes distribution called K3s.

The story is brilliantly told from the other side of the fence, and your palms do get sweaty when watching it.

@Maxs Pick: 🔥 We Didnt Start the Fire: Communication Breakdowns and How to Prevent Them [Slides][Video]
Remember some time ago Dockershim was deprecated in k8s and people all over the world were freaking out, thinking k8s won't run their Docker images anymore?

The story is brilliantly told from the other side of the fence, and your palms do get sweaty when watching it.

Morale: Communication is crucial. Dont just assume what others think. Communicate, check the expectations, adapt. Together. MAY 2021
Infra Newsletter
 
Hi everyone 👋
 
Were continuing the process of the periodic Infra newsletter started some time ago to keep increasing the transparency of our work.

This one is a bit different. Well not only focus on the achievements, but will also share some useful knowledge about infrastructure, and our impressions about the KubeCon EU 2021 conference.
 
 
📓 Table of Contents
 
👩‍💻 Some statistics
💪 Achievements
🤖 Using Renovate to update asdfs .tool-versions
🚀 Triggering Jenkins rubs from GitHub Actions
🧠 Knowledge Sharing
🛂  Dependabot runs have limited permissions in GitHub
 KubeCon EU 2021  
@Ahmed's Pick: 👮 Shifting Policy Enforcement to the Left using GitOps
@Chaima's Pick: 🚀 Take your Project Docs to the Next Level
@Chriss Pick: 🔓TechDocs: Unlocking the Potential of Engineers' Collective Knowledge
@Larss Pick: 🏡 Automating Your Home with K3s and Home Assistant
@Maxs Pick: 🔥 We Didnt Start the Fire: Communication Breakdowns and How to Prevent Them
 
 
👩‍💻 Some Statistics
 
Over previous month (April 2021):
 

 
41 requests
 
answered in #infra, from 9 different teams
  

 
43 tickets
 
completed in Jira, 14 of them coming from other teams' requests
  

 
24k+ builds
 
ran in all Jenkins CI instances, over 800 builds per day!
 
 
💪 Achievements 
 
🤖Using Renovate to update asdfs .tool-versions
Many of Camunda Engineering teams use Renovate to automatically update project dependencies and save time. Some teams also use asdf to easily manage multiple runtimes for their projects and avoid tedious manual setup steps.

Have you been annoyed that Renovate does not support updating asdf dependencies in .tool-versions? Theres a workaround! Check out how Infra is doing it here, here, and in action.

Whom you can ask more about it: @Christian Nicolai
 
 
🚀Triggering Jenkins runs from GitHub Actions
When migrating CI processs to GitHub Actions, its often not feasible to do everything at once - for whatever reason, you might want to keep some legacy jobs in Jenkins.

By leveraging an official Jenkins API, we can now trigger these jobs from any GitHub Actions process. Its also possible to wait for their status and stream the logs.

This API is currently only available for Cawemo CI, but can be enabled on request.

Whom you can ask more about it: @Leonhardt Wille
 
 
 
🧠 Knowledge Sharing
 
🛂 Dependabot runs have limited permissions in GitHub
GitHub recently introduced a change that treats Dependabot PRs as though they are from a forked repository. This means that those PRs are subject to the limited access of e.g. repository secrets and can thereby fail if those are required in a GitHub action.

The Infrastructure team recommends switching to Renovate. If this is not feasible some workarounds can be found in this GitHub issue.
 
 
 
  KubeCon EU 2021
 
This year all Infra team members have participated in the biggest online Kubernetes-related conference in Europe. Wed like to share the talks weve enjoyed most (all talks are now available to the public), to get you inspired, and maybe youre about to join the next KubeCon yourself!
 
 
@Ahmed's Pick: 👮 Shifting Policy Enforcement to the Left using GitOps [Slides][Video]
Sandeep Parikh is a DevRel Engineer at Google Cloud. This talk is an application of DevSecOps concepts, it covers crossroads of different areas like Kubernetes, Open Policy Agent (aka OPA), automation via GitOps, and Shift-left concept. An interesting talk if you would like to know more about security, automation, and modern software practices. However it probably needs some basic knowledge about the mentioned topics.
 
 
@Chaima's Pick: 🚀 Take your Project Docs to the Next Level [Slides][Video]
Celeste Horgan is senior technical writer at the CNCF. She gave a very nice presentation for developers on how to create documentation and what are the main steps that should be present for a good documentation (concept, reference, tasks, and learn more). It was a nice break from very technical topics. Also, the presenter made a very interesting and coherent talk using a story telling way of presenting.
 
 
@Chriss Pick: 🔓 TechDocs: Unlocking the Potential of Engineers' Collective Knowledge [Slides][Video]
Emma Indal is a member of Spotifys technical documentation team (creators of Backstage) and gave a fascinating overview of the scale of their internal documentation platform with thousands of articles for hundreds of services. She shared how they achieved the goal of making documentation a first class citizen along code to improve the engineers experience.
 
 
@Larss Pick: 🏡 Automating Your Home with K3s and Home Assistant [GitHub][Video]
Eddie Zaneski and Jeff Billimek gave a brilliant talk at KubeCon about how they run their home automation with Home Assistant within a Kubernetes cluster at home. For this, they utilized a lightweight and production-ready Kubernetes distribution called K3s.

Both gave interesting insights into their home automation setup and how it can benefit from Kubernetes.

I recommend this talk to everyone interested in Kubernetes and/or home automation.
 
 
@Maxs Pick: 🔥 We Didnt Start the Fire: Communication Breakdowns and How to Prevent Them [Slides][Video]
Remember some time ago Dockershim was deprecated in k8s and people all over the world were freaking out, thinking k8s won't run their Docker images anymore?

The story is brilliantly told from the other side of the fence, and your palms do get sweaty when watching it.

Morale: Communication is crucial. Dont just assume what others think. Communicate, check the expectations, adapt. Together. MAY 2021
